posts.post_content: The CC cost was often added in Ice Age as additional cost for the cantrip. In this case, it would have been okay if it was the basic effect just for ![Blue](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=U&type=symbol). But for 1 mana less, you have the famed [counterspell](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=counterspell), which unconditionally counters the opponent, also available in Ice Age. I was playing heavily during Ice Age and never saw this card in use!
posts.html:

Posted By: bagilis (9/13/2010 12:28:32 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
*"Comparing this to Mana Leak or Force Spike is overlooking the fact that this draws you a card. Mana Leak and Force Spike don't draw you a card. Counter a spell and draw a card for 3 mana is pretty good."*   
   
[Overwhelming Intellect](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Overwhelming Intellect) draws you many cards, but it's expense and situational nature make it bad.
  
   
It's much the same for Force Void. The reason [Daze](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Daze) and [Force Spike](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Force Spike) see any play is that they come online early enough to stop turn one plays, and are easy to hold ready for catching a tapped-out opponent. Holding three mana open is a lot considering the opponent has only to hold open one to play around it. While [Mana Leak](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mana Leak) doesn't come online as early, it still asks the opponent to have more mana open to them than it does of you.
posts.html:
"Comparing this to Mana Leak or Force Spike is overlooking the fact that this draws you a card. Mana Leak and Force Spike don't draw you a card. Counter a spell and draw a card for 3 mana is pretty good."

Overwhelming Intellect draws you many cards, but it's expense and situational nature make it bad.

It's much the same for Force Void. The reason Daze and Force Spike see any play is that they come online early enough to stop turn one plays, and are easy to hold ready for catching a tapped-out opponent. Holding three mana open is a lot considering the opponent has only to hold open one to play around it. While Mana Leak doesn't come online as early, it still asks the opponent to have more mana open to them than it does of you.

posts.post_content: Comparing this to [Mana Leak](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mana Leak) or [Force Spike](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Force Spike) is overlooking the fact that this **draws you a card**. Mana Leak and Force Spike don't draw you a card. Counter a spell and draw a card for 3 mana is pretty good.. Compare this to [Remand](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Remand), [Dismiss](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Dismiss) or [Arcane Denial](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Arcane Denial) . Back in these days there weren't fast-trips like we have today they were slo-trips. A good effect though like [Panic](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Panic) that can easily help you in a game and then draw you a card is very powerful. Come on! This is good. Nothing 'weak' about it. ME5 please ? :(
posts.html:
Comparing this to Mana Leak or Force Spike is overlooking the fact that this draws you a card. Mana Leak and Force Spike don't draw you a card. Counter a spell and draw a card for 3 mana is pretty good.. Compare this to Remand, Dismiss or Arcane Denial . Back in these days there weren't fast-trips like we have today they were slo-trips. A good effect though like Panic that can easily help you in a game and then draw you a card is very powerful. Come on! This is good. Nothing 'weak' about it. ME5 please ? :(
